title: Never Split the Difference by Chris Voss

cards.back: That negotiation is an exercise in tactical empathy and honing those skills can improve your life.

The FBI developed their negotiation methods through iteration while having intense skin in the game. Harvard intellectuals did so through theory. Consequently, the FBI methods were superior.
Voss asks the same open ended questions until they get frustrated and give up
Good negotiator know they need to be ready for surprises. Great negotiators use their skills to reveal the surprises they're certain exist. 
Your mindset should be that of discovery. Learn as much about the situation as possible
Yes can be inauthentic. When you say No, you know you're in control and not just being taken for a ride. For example, always ask "is now a bad time?” Instead of “is now a good time?" If you get a *no* you know the person is going to be focused and not just distractedly playing along.
In general, *that's right* is what you’re looking for. It signals your counterpart believes they’ve come up with the solution themselves. Alternatively, *you're right* is bad and often dismissive.
Use your opponent's deadlines against them. Cars salesman are more likely to give good deals at end of the month, businessmen at end of the financial quarter.
Avoid anchoring (giving the first offer) in monetary bargaining. But beware of sharks who will give a ludicrous anchor to throw you off.
In a job interview or salary negotiation, ask "what does it take to be successful here." That'll give the boss a personal stake in your success. You've just created an unofficial mentor
Who has control in a negotiation the talker or the listener? The listener of course. That's because the talker is revealing information.

cards.front: The three voices you should use when negotiating:
cards.back:
The FM DJ voice: a self-assured voice of calm and reason, use it calm down your counterpart
A positive playful voice: Use most of the time, encourages positivity and cooperation 
An assertive dominant voice: Use with caution

the concept of "birds of a feather flock together." You send subtle signals that you're similar to your counterpart and should be bonding with. Seen often body language. Voss’ recommendation: Repeat the last three words of what the person just said
a type of tactical empathy; understanding your opponents emotions, articulating them, and respectfully verbalizing
identifying all the reason’s you counterpart might be angry with you.
7% of what we communicate is done so through the verbal word, 35% is through the tone and intonation, and 55% is through our body language.

- *how am I supposed to do that?* 
- *thank you for your generous offer but that just doesn't work for me* 
- *I'm sorry but I just can't do that*
- *I'm sorry no*

cards.front: There are three types of negotiators:

cards.back: super high trait C. They prepare a lot and are very calculating but beware that you're not offputting by how cold you are. Hypersensitive to reciprocity. Highly introverted. Use data and reason with them. Not quick to answer calibrated questions
high trait A. Very friendly. Be friendly with them. They might leave out objections or problem areas to avoid conflict

time is money. Perfection not necessary. Winning is the goal. Prioritization of respect. Must be heard. Tell not ask. Every silence is an opportunity to speak more. If you're dealing with this type, mirrors, andcalibrated questions are both excellent options. Look for the that's right
When you control something your counterpart wishes to avoid
when you can provide something that your counterpart desires
when you find inconsistencies in your opponents words and actions. Nobody likes to be a hypocrite find out what your counterparts usual behavior.
Sudden surprising information which changes the balance of leverage in a negotiation
